newsitem.title: MEXICO: Mexico peso reverses strength on U.S. long bond.
newsitem.headline: Mexico peso reverses strength on U.S. long bond.

text.p: The benchmark 48-hour and its 24-hour stablemate reversed earlier firmness to close slightly weaker on Thursday, after local and foreign dealers covered short dollar positions on a late gain in U.S. long bond yields, traders said.
"Banks were short on dollars and decided to step in to square positions when they saw the U.S. long bond was under pressure; that is why the peso turned around," a trader said.
The 48-hour peso 24-hour contracts ended 1.2 centavos and 0.5 of a centavo weaker, respectively, at 7.8710/7.8760 and 7.8620/7.8670 per dollar.
The U.S. 30-year Treasury bond fell 12/32 to yield 7.12 percent in late trade.
Dealers said brokers had also decided to cover short dollar positions ahead of inflation data that were expected shortly after the close of trade.
"The market opened short (on dollars) because dealers thought inflation figures would be good, but they ended up reconsidering and bought back dollars," another trader said.
A Reuters survey of financial firms MXAAP showed they expected consumer inflation for April 1-15 to be an avaerage of 0.64 percent.
Nonetheless, several dealers in late trade said they were expecting consumer prices to have risen by 0.72 percent.
Same-day peso contracts had earlier closed 2.6 centavos firmer at 7.8430/7.8470 per dollar.
